line: Proceedings of the Twenty-Ninth International
label: paragraph

line: Florida Artificial Intelligence Research Society Conference
label: paragraph

line: TAO: System for Table Detection and Extraction from PDF Documents
label: heading

line: Martha O. Perez-Arriaga, Trilce Estrada, and Soraya Abad-Mota
label: heading

line: Departments of Computer Science, and Electrical and Computer Engineering
label: paragraph

line: University of New Mexico
label: paragraph

line: {marperez, estrada, soraya}@cs.unm.edu
label: paragraph

line: Abstract
label: heading

line: Digital documents present knowledge in most areas of
label: paragraph

line: study, exchanging and communicating information in a
label: paragraph

line: portable way. To better use the knowledge embedded
label: paragraph

line: in an ever-growing information source, effective tools
label: paragraph

line: for automatic information extraction are needed. Tables
label: paragraph

line: are crucial information elements in documents of sci-
label: paragraph

line: entiﬁc nature. Most publications use tables to represent
label: paragraph

line: and report concrete ﬁndings of research. Current meth-
label: paragraph

line: ods used to extract table data from PDF documents lack
label: paragraph

line: precision in detecting, extracting, and representing data
label: paragraph

line: from diverse layouts.
label: paragraph

line: We present the system TAble Organization (TAO) to
label: paragraph

line: automatically detect, extract and organize information
label: paragraph

line: from tables in PDF documents. TAO uses a process-
label: paragraph

line: ing, based on the k-nearest neighbor method and lay-
label: paragraph

line: out heuristics, to detect tables within a document and to
label: paragraph

line: extract table information. This system generates an en-
label: paragraph

line: riched representation of the data extracted from tables
label: paragraph

line: in the PDF documents. TAO’s performance is compara-
label: paragraph

line: ble to other table extraction methods, but it overcomes
label: paragraph

line: some related work limitations and proves to be more ro-
label: paragraph

line: bust in experiments with diverse document layouts.
label: paragraph

line: 1 Introduction
label: heading

line: Scientiﬁc digital documents allow us to present and share in-
label: paragraph

line: formation in different areas of knowledge. The ever-growing
label: paragraph

line: numberofdocumentsavailableontheInternetmakesitdifﬁ-
label: paragraph

line: cult to analyze them at the same pace they are produced. The
label: paragraph

line: myriad topics and ways in which digital documents present
label: paragraph

line: the information hinder the extraction and management of
label: paragraph

line: their contents.
label: paragraph

line: Scientiﬁc publications use tables to represent results and
label: paragraph

line: associations. Tables are simple representations of informa-
label: paragraph

line: tion that show relationships between concepts. People iden-
label: paragraph

line: tify tables within documents easily, but given the number of
label: paragraph

line: documents to analyze, the identiﬁcation is time consuming.
label: paragraph

line: Performingthistaskautomaticallyisdifﬁcultduetothevari-
label: paragraph

line: ety of document formats (e.g., PDF, HTML), tables’ layouts
label: paragraph

line: and types of information.
label: paragraph

line: The main challenge in detecting tables in digital docu-
label: paragraph

line: ments is that tables are mixed with other elements, such
label: paragraph

line: Copyright c? 2016, Association for the Advancement of Artiﬁcial
label: paragraph

line: Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.
label: paragraph

line: as ﬁgures and text. Also, the PDF documents present more
label: paragraph

line: challenges to detect tables due to the lack of table tags. Our
label: paragraph

line: approach focuses on PDF documents.
label: paragraph

line: Current methods (Liu et al. 2007; Oro and Ruffolo 2009)
label: paragraph

line: for automatic table detection and extraction in PDF docu-
label: paragraph

line: ments are useful, but still have some restrictions. These re-
label: paragraph

line: strictions include detection of tables only in documents with
label: paragraph

line: single column, detection relying on patterns not present in
label: paragraph

line: all tables, and extraction lacking elements needed to accu-
label: paragraph

line: rately reconstruct the information provided in a table. To
label: paragraph

line: overcome these limitations, we propose the TAble Organi-
label: paragraph

line: zation (TAO) system that not only provides automatic table
label: paragraph

line: detectionandextractionindigitaldocuments,butalsogener-
label: paragraph

line: ates a detailed representation of table elements for structural
label: paragraph

line: and functional analyses.
label: paragraph

line: TAO is efﬁcient, comprehensive and robust. It is efﬁcient
label: paragraph

line: because it takes advantage of the structure formed by tables,
label: paragraph

line: avoiding an exhaustive search of table elements where there
label: paragraph

line: is no such structure. It is comprehensive because it discovers
label: paragraph

line: metadata (e.g., header, font, data type, coordinates) and data
label: paragraph

line: from tables embedded in a document. Finally, TAO is robust
label: paragraph

line: because it does not depend on ﬁxed patterns or layouts to
label: paragraph

line: detect tables, and it is able to detect them on different lay-
label: paragraph

line: out documents (see Section 2). Even though scientiﬁc pub-
label: paragraph

line: lications are an important target for TAO, its methods serve
label: paragraph

line: the purpose of extracting information from any PDF doc-
label: paragraph

line: ument containing tables. TAO is compared to related work
label: paragraph

line: (see Sections 3,4). TAO’s output portable format facilitates
label: paragraph

line: information organization and sharing, and further analysis
label: paragraph

line: (see Section 5).
label: paragraph

line: Our main contributions are: 1) an adaptive method to de-
label: paragraph

line: tect and extract tables’ information, 2) an annotated repre-
label: paragraph

line: sentation of the information extracted from tables for further
label: paragraph

line: structural, functional, and semantic analyses, and 3) a web-
label: paragraph

line: based prototype of the system at http://integra.cs.unm.edu.
label: paragraph

line: 2 Table Detection and Extraction
label: heading

line: The TAble Organization (TAO) system is capable of detect-
label: paragraph

line: ing and recognizing tables within PDF documents. Table
label: paragraph

line: detection is the process of identifying tables from a docu-
label: paragraph

line: ment, and table recognition of identifying and extracting the
label: paragraph

line: cells contained in a table (Hu et al. 1999). To acomplish this
label: paragraph

line: processing, TAO combines a supervised machine learning
label: paragraph

line: method with layout heuristics, and consists of three main
label: paragraph

line: modules: 1) document conversion, 2) table detection, and 3)
label: paragraph

line: table extraction, (see Figure 1).
label: paragraph

line: TAO’s input is a PDF document. Using PDFMiner, the
label: paragraph

line: PDF document is converted to an XML format contain-
label: paragraph

line: ing all elements in the document (e.g., characters, ﬁgure’s
label: paragraph

line: placeholders, layouts). PDFMiner’s output includes separate
label: paragraph

line: XML tags for every character and every space. The second
label: paragraph

line: module, table detection, parses this large XML ﬁle and iden-
label: paragraph

line: tiﬁes table candidates, storing them in a per-page fashion.
label: paragraph

line: The third module, table extraction, uses the table candidates
label: paragraph

line: to ﬁnd particular cells and their content. Once the tables
label: paragraph

line: are identiﬁed, this module augments tables with informa-
label: paragraph

line: tion regarding their metadata and position within the doc-
label: paragraph

line: ument. TAO’s output is a JSON document with the table’s
label: paragraph

line: information and augmented information extracted from the
label: paragraph

line: PDF. Optionally, this information can be stored in a NOSQL
label: paragraph

line: database for easy access and search. In the following sec-
label: paragraph

line: tions, we describe the methods built into the system to per-
label: paragraph

line: form automatic table detection and extraction.
label: paragraph

line: Figure 1: The TAble Organization (TAO) system
label: paragraph

line: Document Conversion
label: heading

line: Document conversion uses the PDFMiner (Shinyama 2010)
label: paragraph

line: extraction tool, which allows converting PDF documents to
label: paragraph

line: text, HTML, XML, and tagged PDF formats. PDFMiner
label: paragraph

line: outputs the coordinates of the text, font style and size for
label: paragraph

line: each character into an XML ﬁle. We evaluated other con-
label: paragraph

line: verters (Noonburg 2009; Litchﬁeld 2004), but we selected
label: paragraph

line: PDFMiner because it analyzes the structure of the informa-
label: paragraph

line: tion on each page, providing a detailed hierarchy of grouped
label: paragraph

line: elements based on their spatial relationships in the doc-
label: paragraph

line: ument. In addition, PDFMiner has been maintained and
label: paragraph

line: widely adopted.
label: paragraph

line: PDFMiner converts a PDF ﬁle into an XML representa-
label: paragraph

line: tion, and generates a body and a layout for each page of
label: paragraph

line: the document. The body is formed by text boxes, text lines
label: paragraph

line: and text (see Figure 3 for an example). Text boxes include
label: paragraph

line: an identiﬁer (id), and the coordinates (x1,y1) represent top-
label: paragraph

line: left and (x2,y2) bottom-right corners of the bounding box
label: paragraph

line: (bbox). Text boxes are composed of text lines. Text lines
label: paragraph

line: are composed of text tags. Each text tag contains a single
label: paragraph

line: character. Characters grouped in text lines form one or more
label: paragraph

line: words. A text line also includes its corresponding bounding
label: paragraph

line: box (bbox) coordinates. PDFMiner provides coordinates,
label: paragraph

line: text font, and text size for each character.
label: paragraph

line: The layout includes elements such as text groups and text
label: paragraph

line: boxes. Text box elements of the layout are also found in the
label: paragraph

line: body. The difference is that in the layout, text boxes are or-
label: paragraph

line: ganized into text groups, indicating the coordinates of the
label: paragraph

line: information structure. In the body, text boxes contain all
label: paragraph

line: the page information, character by character. PDFMiner’s
label: paragraph

line: output is comprehensive and long. For example, for a
label: paragraph

line: 10-page IEEE research paper, PDFMiner outputs approxi-
label: paragraph

line: mately 60,000 lines, which varies with a document’s con-
label: paragraph

line: tent. Therefore, it is practically impossible to parse, detect
label: paragraph

line: and extract information manually, and not a trivial task to
label: paragraph

line: do so automatically. In the remainder of this section, we
label: paragraph

line: use TAO to parse this XML output and generate cleanly ex-
label: paragraph

line: tracted and annotated table structures.
label: paragraph

line: Table Detection
label: heading

line: Our table detection module identiﬁes tables within the lay-
label: paragraph

line: out of the XML output provided by PDFMiner. This output
label: paragraph

line: does not discriminate between text in normal paragraphs, ta-
label: paragraph

line: bles or ﬁgures. The document structure elements are rep-
label: paragraph

line: resented by group boxes and text boxes. Thus, TAO per-
label: paragraph

line: forms a structural analysis to identify sets of text boxes that
label: paragraph

line: are probable table candidates. The table detection process
label: paragraph

line: includes four steps: 1) comprehensive identiﬁcation of text
label: paragraph

line: boxes within text groups, 2) distance calculation among text
label: paragraph

line: boxes, 3) identiﬁcation of structural relationships, and 4)
label: paragraph

line: generation of table candidates.
label: paragraph

line: In PDFMiner’s output, the coordinates of a page are top-
label: paragraph

line: left (0,0) and bottom-right (approximately 750,850). Text
label: paragraph

line: boxes are contained within text groups in the layout of each
label: paragraph

line: page. A text box may contain one or more table elements.
label: paragraph

line: For each text group, we identify the set T of all text boxes
label: paragraph

line: in it. In the table detection process, we ﬁrst create a list con-
label: paragraph

line: taining all the text box identiﬁers (id) on each page. Then,
label: paragraph

line: for each pair (a,b) of text boxes ∈ T, we compute their Man-
label: paragraph

line: hattan distance using their top-left (x1,y1) and bottom-right
label: paragraph

line: (x2,y2) coordinates. We store the proximity calculations in
label: paragraph

line: an upper-traingular matrix Mdiff. Each element in the ma-
label: paragraph

line: trix contains the distance of the top-left coordinates between
label: paragraph

line: a and b for the ﬁrst corners of the text boxes Mdiff[a,b,1] =
label: paragraph

line: [(a.x1−b.x1),(a.y1−b.y1)] and the distance of the bottom-
label: paragraph

line: right coordinates between a and b for the second corners of
label: paragraph

line: the text boxes Mdiff[a,b,2] = [(a.x2−b.x2),(a.y2−b.y2)].
label: paragraph

line: The distance matrix Mdiff contains the proximity of text
label: paragraph

line: box pairs, deﬁning global structural relationships (i.e., rows
label: paragraph

line: and columns) among multiple text boxes. To identify mul-
label: paragraph

line: tiple columns, a layout heuristic detects columns when two
label: paragraph

line: or more text boxes have an alignment, (i.e., text boxes inter-
label: paragraph

line: sect horizontally). In the same way, a heuristic for vertical
label: paragraph

line: intersection indicates that the elements form a row. Through
label: paragraph

line: experimentation we learned that the alignments have mini-
label: paragraph

line: mal variation because the coordinates of each page are ﬁxed.
label: paragraph

line: Because columns are generally aligned to the left, right or
label: paragraph

line: center, we ﬁnd more variation in the column alignment than
label: paragraph

line: inrows.Therefore,wedetectcolumns,comparingalignment
label: paragraph

line: with a threshold distance of at most t = ±23 points to either
label: paragraph

line: side (i.e., about 2 characters with font size 10). For rows,
label: paragraph

line: the thresholds are smaller because they have minimal top
label: paragraph

line: or bottom alignments. Thus, to identify rows, the distance
label: paragraph

line: threshold is t±10 (i.e., 1 character) for the separation above
label: paragraph

line: a text box and t ± 2 for below.
label: paragraph

line: Figure 2: Identiﬁcation of structural relationships among
label: paragraph

line: text boxes
label: paragraph

line: Pairs whose proximity is less than or equal to the thresh-
label: paragraph

line: olds are aligned, forming either a row or a column. All the
label: paragraph

line: text boxes in the same row or column are joined. The aligned
label: paragraph

line: text boxes represent the table candidates. Figure 2 shows six
label: paragraph

line: text boxes (a,b,c,d,e,f) with each one displaying their align-
label: paragraph

line: ments as vertical or horizontal thinarrows. Boxeswhose dis-
label: paragraph

line: tance is within the threshold limits are grouped either verti-
label: paragraph

line: cally or horizontally, forming a preliminary structural orga-
label: paragraph

line: nization of the table, which contains two columns and three
label: paragraph

line: rows.
label: paragraph

line: Table Extraction
label: heading

line: The table extraction module of TAO recognizes the actual
label: paragraph

line: tables, locating the cells (i.e., the intersection between a row
label: paragraph

line: and a column) that belong to a particular table, and storing
label: paragraph

line: the tables found on each page of the document. The text con-
label: paragraph

line: tained in each cell of the table is extracted and saved in an
label: paragraph

line: explicit data structure, including additional information re-
label: paragraph

line: lated to the cell. The table extraction module performs the
label: paragraph

line: Table recognition and Table composition tasks.
label: paragraph

line: In Table recognition, we use the body of the XML out-
label: paragraph

line: put produced by PDFMiner and table candidates obtained
label: paragraph

line: from the Table detection module. To extract words located
label: paragraph

line: in cells of the table, we follow a two-phase process: ﬁrst, we
label: paragraph

line: identify cells and then reconstruct the text within each cell.
label: paragraph

line: To detect cells in the table, we use a similar approach to the
label: paragraph

line: one explained in the previous section, but instead of compar-
label: paragraph

line: ing and aligning text boxes, we compare text lines. The text
label: paragraph

line: boxes are a coarse representation of possible table layouts,
label: paragraph

line: while text lines are a more accurate way to detect speciﬁc
label: paragraph

line: table elements (i.e., words in table cells). Thus, for this step
label: paragraph

line: we also calculate an upper-triangular distance matrix Md2 to
label: paragraph

line: store the proximity between pairs of text lines.
label: paragraph

line: Because we identify table information in diverse formats,
label: paragraph

line: a learning process to ﬁnd table alignments is appropriate.
label: paragraph

line: We analyzed the k-nearest neighbor (K-NN) and locally
label: paragraph

line: weighted regressions methods, the former being faster and
label: paragraph

line: more efﬁcient with 4 neighbors, uniform weighting, and
label: paragraph

line: Eucledian distance. Our analysis to determine parameters
label: paragraph

line: found no improvement to give more weight to closer neigh-
label: paragraph

line: bors. Therefore, the K-NN regression was applied to learn
label: paragraph

line: the threshold t, (i.e., maximum alignment in a column), to
label: paragraph

line: identify the ids of text lines in the same column. We use the
label: paragraph

line: scikit tool (Pedregosa et al. 2011). The training data con-
label: paragraph

line: tains 300 different samples with the font size of different
label: paragraph

line: tables and their alignment between columns. To avoid noise,
label: paragraph

line: we take the maximum alignment from the samples with
label: paragraph

line: the same font size, yielding 55 unique samples. Recall that
label: paragraph

line: the coordinates (x1,y1) represent the top-left and (x2,y2)
label: paragraph

line: bottom-right corners of the bbox. For each pair of text lines
label: paragraph

line: (p,q) ∈ Md2, if p.x1 − q.x1 < t and p.x2 − q.x2 < t then
label: paragraph

line: (p,q) are in the same column, we add their ids to the list
label: paragraph

line: of columns LC. Similarly, if p.y1 − q.y1 < fontsize and
label: paragraph

line: p.y2 − q.y2 < fontsize then (p,q) are in the same row,
label: paragraph

line: we add their ids to the list of rows LR. The font size repre-
label: paragraph

line: sents the threshold of row separation within tables because
label: paragraph

line: the alignment cannot be greater than the height of a single
label: paragraph

line: row, which measures at least the font size. To identify cells
label: paragraph

line: and reconstruct text within cells such as words and numbers,
label: paragraph

line: we use the lists of columns LC and rows LR obtained in the
label: paragraph

line: previous step. A cell in a table is the intersection of a column
label: paragraph

line: c in LC and a row r in LR, cell[r,c] ← LR(r) ∩ LC(c).
label: paragraph

line: The process outputs a ﬁle containing all the cells grouped
label: paragraph

line: by column and row, and its associated text line. The grouped
label: paragraph

line: text lines allow us to explore their associated text tags and
label: paragraph

line: extract all the words in a particular cell.
label: paragraph

line: In text extraction, for each text line in a particular cell,
label: paragraph

line: we identify its children text tags and extract a) the particular
label: paragraph

line: character, b) text box id, c) text line id, d) bbox coordinates,
label: paragraph

line: e)textfont,andf)textsize.PDFMinermaygeneratetextline
label: paragraph

line: identiﬁers unsorted. Thus, ﬁnding two consecutive text line
label: paragraph

line: ids in a table cell does not mean that the coordinates of these
label: paragraph

line: text lines are sorted in the original Cartesian plane. To solve
label: paragraph

line: this issue, we organize table elements using coordinates to
label: paragraph

line: produce sorted and aligned text for the table cell. Figure 3
label: paragraph

line: shows the text reconstruction process for a cell composed of
label: paragraph

line: one text line containing four text tags.
label: paragraph

line: Figure 3: Text reconstruction from a text line in a table cell
label: paragraph

line: To avoid redundant information, we verify that the cells
label: paragraph

line: contained in rows match the ones in columns. The cells are
label: paragraph

line: grouped by row, preserving the coordinates of each cell to
label: paragraph

line: locate the table cells’ positions. Finally, the cells identiﬁed
label: paragraph

line: in a table and their contents are stored indicating the page on
label: paragraph

line: which they appear in the original document. Up to this point,
label: paragraph

line: multiple tables can still be stored together if they appear on
label: paragraph

line: the same page.
label: paragraph

line: Table composition performs table separation in the doc-
label: paragraph

line: ument, and classiﬁes elements of tables as header or data.
label: paragraph

line: Header refers to a label representing table information (i.e.,
label: paragraph

line: row or column headers), while data is the actual content or
label: paragraph

line: body of the table. The composition task retrieves all cells
label: paragraph

line: on a particular page, sorts coordinates of text cells grouped
label: paragraph

line: by row, and calculates row separation. If, for a speciﬁc pair
label: paragraph

line: of neighbor rows, this separation is larger than a threshold
label: paragraph

line: ttable, we classify and assign an identiﬁer for a new table.
label: paragraph

line: To learn ttable, the K-NN regression method was applied as
label: paragraph

line: in table recognition. The training data contains 300 differ-
label: paragraph

line: ent samples of font size and row separation between tables.
label: paragraph

line: To avoid noise, we have 55 unique font sizes related to its
label: paragraph

line: maximum row separation.
label: paragraph

line: Once each table is separated as an entity, cells are classi-
label: paragraph

line: ﬁed into data or header. The bold font style of the text in the
label: paragraph

line: cell classiﬁes text as a header, even though it is not at the
label: paragraph

line: top row. This heuristic may fail for customized documents,
label: paragraph

line: but is general enough to capture relevant cell differences in
label: paragraph

line: documents. A cell is classiﬁed as a header when it it is in a
label: paragraph

line: top position that groups some cells under it. Using pattern
label: paragraph

line: matching, we also classify the cell content by data type (i.e.,
label: paragraph

line: numeric or string of characters).
label: paragraph

line: The output of this component is an explicit table repre-
label: paragraph

line: sentation that can be easily ported to a database for efﬁ-
label: paragraph

line: cient search. The ﬁle contains a) extracted text of table cells
label: paragraph

line: grouped by row, indicating header (i.e., metadata) or data;
label: paragraph

line: b) provenance information associated with the cells consist-
label: paragraph

line: ing of identiﬁers of text boxes and text lines from where the
label: paragraph

line: text was identiﬁed; c) position of tables on each page; and
label: paragraph

line: d) metadata attributes including coordinates of the text, text
label: paragraph

line: size, text font, and data type. Figure 4 shows the extracted
label: paragraph

line: information from four table cells.
label: paragraph

line: Figure 4: Sample of table cells represented by TAO
label: paragraph

line: 3 Evaluation
label: heading

line: To evaluate the usefulness and generality of TAO compared
label: paragraph

line: to other PDF table extractors, a systematic assessment of its
label: paragraph

line: capability to detect tables and content was performed. De-
label: paragraph

line: tecting tables means identifying all the tabular elements in
label: paragraph

line: the PDF documents, whether or not their content was recog-
label: paragraph

line: nized accurately. Thus, we computed precision and recall.
label: paragraph

line: Precision is the fraction of the correct number of tables iden-
label: paragraph

line: tiﬁed divided by the total number of tables found. Recall
label: paragraph

line: is the fraction of correct tables found, divided by the total
label: paragraph

line: number of tables in the documents. The F1-measure com-
label: paragraph

line: bines precision and recall. Recognizing tables means cor-
label: paragraph

line: rectly identifying and associating cell’s content with a par-
label: paragraph

line: ticular table. For the recognition task, table cells recognized
label: paragraph

line: were used to measure precision and recall.
label: paragraph

line: We compared and contrasted the performance of TAO
label: paragraph

line: with respect to two other table extractors: Pdf-trex and Ta-
label: paragraph

line: bleSeer (see Section 4). Pdf-trex code was unavailable, thus
label: paragraph

line: wereporttheprecisionandrecallpublishedin(Oroand Ruf-
label: paragraph

line: folo 2009). Because TableSeer’s code was publicly available
label: paragraph

line: at http://tableseer.soft112.com/, we produced its outputs for
label: paragraph

line: all experiments.
label: paragraph

line: The ﬁrst dataset TREX described in (Oro and Ruffolo
label: paragraph

line: was publicly available at http://staff.icar.cnr.it/ruffolo/
label: paragraph

line: pdftrex/dataset.zip. This dataset was intended to be a stan-
label: paragraph

line: dardbenchmarkforautomatictableextractionwith100PDF
label: paragraph

line: single-column documents in the English and Italian lan-
label: paragraph

line: guages, containing more than 100 pages with around 150
label: paragraph

line: tables. TREX does not reﬂect the format of standard research
label: paragraph

line: papers, but, rather, technical reports containing tables with a
label: paragraph

line: variety of formats and styles.
label: paragraph

line: The second dataset, obtained from the Cornell University
label: paragraph

line: Library site at http://arxiv.org/, comprised of twenty scien-
label: paragraph

line: tiﬁc publications selected randomly. Two of them did not
label: paragraph

line: contain tables. This dataset, to which we refer to as COR-
label: paragraph

line: NELL, included one- and two-column documents containing
label: paragraph

line: more than 300 pages with 79 tables. This dataset allowed
label: paragraph

line: us to measure TAO’s performance in multiple page scien-
label: paragraph

line: tiﬁc publications. Additionally, we used the COMBINED
label: paragraph

line: dataset results from the merging of the TREX and COR-
label: paragraph

line: NELL datasets to generate a more diverse one.
label: paragraph

line: We prepared the gold standard, (i.e., the actual informa-
label: paragraph

line: tion from the tables in the datasets). A program compared
label: paragraph

line: the gold standard against the cells extracted and organized
label: paragraph

line: by TAO, and assisted to calculate the recall and precision.
label: paragraph

line: Results and Discussion
label: heading

line: In the ﬁrst set of experiments, we compared TAO, Pdf-trex,
label: paragraph

line: and TableSeer using the TREX dataset. The TAO’s output
label: paragraph

line: from this dataset yielded an F1-measure of 91.9% for ta-
label: paragraph

line: ble detection and 86.4% for recognition. Pdf-trex’s results
label: paragraph

line: in (Oro and Ruffolo 2009) had an F1-measure of 91.7%
label: paragraph

line: for table detection and of 84.6% for recognition. For this
label: paragraph

line: dataset, we found 148 tables and Pdf-trex reports 164. We
label: paragraph

line: believe that this difference is because we did not account
label: paragraph

line: lists as tables. TAO’s reliance on PDFMiner can be a limita-
label: paragraph

line: tion because this converter cannot extract information from
label: paragraph

line: a PDF ﬁle when the document is password protected or mal-
label: paragraph

line: formed. Still, PDFMiner converted 89 PDF documents out
label: paragraph

line: of 100. While TAO detected 137 tables out of the 148 and
label: paragraph

line: also identiﬁed 12,504 correct table cells out of 14,466, Ta-
label: paragraph

line: bleSeer performed badly for this set of experiments identi-
label: paragraph

line: fying only 18 tables, whose F1-measure was 21.6% for ta-
label: paragraph

line: ble detection and 5.0% for recognition. This poor perfor-
label: paragraph

line: mance is due to the fact that this dataset does not adhere
label: paragraph

line: to the common rigorous formatting standards for scientiﬁc
label: paragraph

line: publications. Therefore, TAO performed similarly to Pdf-
label: paragraph

line: trex, but better than TableSeer. From the ﬁrst experiment,
label: paragraph

line: we corroborated that TAO adapts the thresholds depending
label: paragraph

line: on the different PDF documents’ font sizes. Because tables
label: paragraph

line: are composed of rows and columns in any language, TAO’s
label: paragraph

line: structural approach was able to detect tables in Italian and
label: paragraph

line: Table 1: Experiments using COMBINED
label: paragraph

line: Method Precision Recall F1 measure
label: paragraph

line: English. The language poses a challenge for semantic anal-
label: paragraph

line: ysis on table’s cells.
label: paragraph

line: Our second experiment used the CORNELL dataset.
label: paragraph

line: TAO’s output yielded an F1-measure of 87.0% for Table de-
label: paragraph

line: tection and 91.1% for recognition. TableSeer yielded an F1-
label: paragraph

line: measure of 84.9% for detection and 89.5% for recognition.
label: paragraph

line: TAO detected 67 tables, and TableSeer 62. Also, TAO de-
label: paragraph

line: tected 4,738 out of 6,003 text cells. For this and the next
label: paragraph

line: experiments, Pdf-trex was not evaluated because it was un-
label: paragraph

line: available. One limitation of TAO using this dataset is that
label: paragraph

line: it produced more false positives (i.e., ﬁgures and equations)
label: paragraph

line: than TableSeer. To solve this problem, we need to detect the
label: paragraph

line: rows that do not contain table cells, but other elements, such
label: paragraph

line: as graphs. TAO may extract the information of two different
label: paragraph

line: cells into a unique cell. Even though this issue is related to
label: paragraph

line: PDFMiner’s output, we need to analyze cells further to pro-
label: paragraph

line: duce more accurate information. Although it is uncommon
label: paragraph

line: to ﬁnd two consecutive horizontal tables, TAO needs to learn
label: paragraph

line: how to separate them. The distance between table rows and
label: paragraph

line: two consecutive tables may vary in a single document, mak-
label: paragraph

line: ing it more difﬁcult for TAO to separate tables consistenly.
label: paragraph

line: However, TAO still performs satisfactorily.
label: paragraph

line: Finally, for completeness and to quantitatively assess the
label: paragraph

line: generality of our method, we report aggregated experiments
label: paragraph

line: using the COMBINED dataset. Table 1 reports a summary
label: paragraph

line: for table detection and recognition for TAO and TableSeer.
label: paragraph

line: TAO is more robust and general because TableSeer depends
label: paragraph

line: on particular keywords to perform accurate Table Detection.
label: paragraph

line: TAO recognized and extracted 17,242 correct table cells,
label: paragraph

line: while TableSeer recognized only 6,389. Similarly, TAO is
label: paragraph

line: more general and robust than Pdf-trex because it can han-
label: paragraph

line: dle double-column documents and Pdf-trex cannot, as doc-
label: paragraph

line: umented in (Oro and Ruffolo 2009).
label: paragraph

line: The K-NN method produced rapid and accurate results
label: paragraph

line: using training data with characteristics of different table for-
label: paragraph

line: mats. The training sets can increment data from more table
label: paragraph

line: formats. TAO’s prototype enables to submit a PDF docu-
label: paragraph

line: ment online, and receive the output by email with the orga-
label: paragraph

line: nized table’s information in JSON.
label: paragraph

line: 4 Related Work
label: heading

line: This section describes brieﬂy a) general deﬁnitions of ta-
label: paragraph

line: ble identiﬁcation, b) document converters, and c) works that
label: paragraph

line: perform table identiﬁcation and to which we compare TAO’s
label: paragraph

line: performance.
label: paragraph

line: Wang analyzes the importance of the physical and logical
label: paragraph

line: elementsintables(Wang1996),anddescribesthemaintable
label: paragraph

line: functions: to identify, understand, search and compare infor-
label: paragraph

line: mation. Hurst describes a model to represent tables, includ-
label: paragraph

line: ing graphical, physical, functional, structural and semantic
label: paragraph

line: components (Hurst 2000). We focus on table identiﬁcation,
label: paragraph

line: which can be divided into table detection and recognition
label: paragraph

line: (Hu et al. 1999). TAO automatically performs these tasks,
label: paragraph

line: which are also known as table processing in (Embley et al.
label: paragraph

line: 2006). Table processing analyzes the physical and logical
label: paragraph

line: structures of a table. The physical structure of a table is the
label: paragraph

line: location of regions containing parts of the table, and the log-
label: paragraph

line: ical structure is the type of regions that compose the table
label: paragraph

line: (Zanibbi, Blostein, and Cordy 2004). Zanibbi et al. classify
label: paragraph

line: table processing according to the approach used to recognize
label: paragraph

line: tables, such as layout (Hu et al. 1999), heuristics (Liu et al.
label: paragraph

line: and statistical methods (Liu et al. 2009). TAO uses a
label: paragraph

line: combination of heuristics with the k-nn statistical method.
label: paragraph

line: Different document formats contain tables in HTML,
label: paragraph

line: XML,textandPDF.WefocusonthePDFformat.MostPDF
label: paragraph

line: documents lack tags, which can indicate the existence of ta-
label: paragraph

line: bles, such as in HTML. To facilitate the management and
label: paragraph

line: understanding of table information some works convert ta-
label: paragraph

line: bles from PDF documents to another format, such as HTML
label: paragraph

line: (Hassan 2003). The converters assist extracting table infor-
label: paragraph

line: mationfromdigitaldocuments,andincludePDFBoxusedin
label: paragraph

line: (Liu et al. 2007), Jpedal used in (Hassan 2003), PDFlib TET
label: paragraph

line: used in (Liu et al. 2009), and PDFMiner (Shinyama 2010)
label: paragraph

line: used in TAO. PDFMiner also converts PDF documents to
label: paragraph

line: HTML. However, it does not identify table tags. The con-
label: paragraph

line: verters are powerful, but they may suffer from text sequence
label: paragraph

line: errors (Liu, Mitra, and Giles 2008), which occur when the
label: paragraph

line: converter tool shows the text in a different order than the
label: paragraph

line: original PDF document. However, some converters show co-
label: paragraph

line: ordinates to process the right order.
label: paragraph

line: TableSeer (Liu et al. 2007), Pdf-trex (Oro and Ruffolo
label: paragraph

line: and TAO identify tables in PDF documents. Besides
label: paragraph

line: performing table identiﬁcation, TableSeer is a table search
label: paragraph

line: engine that crawls digital libraries, indexes and ranks tables.
label: paragraph

line: TableSeer gets words from a PDF converter, and forms lines.
label: paragraph

line: From the lines, TableSeer detects table structure and meta-
label: paragraph

line: data using heuristics rules based on font size, ﬁxed pattern
label: paragraph

line: matching (e.g., TABLE), and white spaces. TAO is indepen-
label: paragraph

line: dent of using pattern matching to detect tables. TableSeer
label: paragraph

line: discovers other metadata for table search, such as captions
label: paragraph

line: and the publication’s name. It also determines data type, lay-
label: paragraph

line: out metadata (e.g., number of columns and rows), and the
label: paragraph

line: position of a table within the document. However, for the ta-
label: paragraph

line: ble’s content it only shows the coordinates of the columns.
label: paragraph

line: An extracted cell represented in a different position makes it
label: paragraph

line: difﬁcult to recover the actual cell’s position in a table. TAO’s
label: paragraph

line: output contains metadata for a table’s cell (e.g., coordinates,
label: paragraph

line: font style), providing the precise location and attributes re-
label: paragraph

line: quired to reconstruct tables in their original format. Table-
label: paragraph

line: Seer and TAO depend on PDF converters.
label: paragraph

line: Pdf-trex detects text and table areas, aligning and group-
label: paragraph

line: ing text with spatial relationships. Tableseer and Pdf-trex
label: paragraph

line: search elements in a table line by line, which differs from
label: paragraph

line: TAO’s top-down approach which identiﬁes structure before
label: paragraph

line: analyzing the speciﬁc lines that may belong to a table. TAO
label: paragraph

line: and Pdf-trex use similar heuristics to detect columns and
label: paragraph

line: rows, allowing them to detect tables in documents in the
label: paragraph

line: English and Italian languages. Also, Pdf-trex uses an ag-
label: paragraph

line: glomerative hierarchical clustering algorithm to build seg-
label: paragraph

line: ments and blocks that form table structure. Similar to TAO,
label: paragraph

line: Pdf-trex generates coordinates for an extracted table’s infor-
label: paragraph

line: mation. However, Pdf-trex’s output lacks other metadata at-
label: paragraph

line: tributes to recover a table’s format and style. While Pdf-trex
label: paragraph

line: extracts tables only in single-column documents, TAO con-
label: paragraph

line: siders single- and multiple-column documents. A work in
label: paragraph

line: (Fang et al. 2011) detects multiple-columns. However, this
label: paragraph

line: work is unavailable for comparison.
label: paragraph

line: TAO’s web-based prototype enables a user to upload a pdf
label: paragraph

line: document, andreceiveorganizedtableinformationbyemail.
label: paragraph

line: TAO can be conﬁgured to process multiple PDF documents
label: paragraph

line: and generate an output for each. TableSeer and Pdf-trex pro-
label: paragraph

line: duce XML code to represent tables, while TAO produces a
label: paragraph

line: JSON format.
label: paragraph

line: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
label: heading

line: The TAble Organization (TAO) system was developed to au-
label: paragraph

line: tomatically detect, extract, and organize tables from PDF
label: paragraph

line: documents. TAO beneﬁts from PDFMiner to convert PDF
label: paragraph

line: documents to XML format. We deﬁned heuristics, training
label: paragraph

line: data, and learning methods to process the XML, detecting
label: paragraph

line: the location of the tables within the document and extract-
label: paragraph

line: ing the corresponding table cells.
label: paragraph

line: TAO was implemented using document conversion, table
label: paragraph

line: detection and extraction; it generates its output in a JSON
label: paragraph

line: document for information interoperability. The table infor-
label: paragraph

line: mation from the original PDF document is preserved and
label: paragraph

line: enriched with data not displayed in the PDF document, such
label: paragraph

line: as text font and coordinates in table cells. The extra informa-
label: paragraph

line: tion helps locate the table cells’ position and format for bet-
label: paragraph

line: ter representation. The output document can easily be stored
label: paragraph

line: and managed in a database to facilitate analysis, sharing, and
label: paragraph

line: collaboration.
label: paragraph

line: We evaluated TAO on varied PDF documents with more
label: paragraph

line: than 225 tables, and compared its performance to related
label: paragraph

line: work. TAO overcame related work limitations. It performed
label: paragraph

line: satisfactorily not only on scientiﬁc documents, but also on
label: paragraph

line: non-scientiﬁc documents. In addition, it extracted tables’ in-
label: paragraph

line: formation on PDF documents with large and small number
label: paragraph

line: of pages, with single and double columns, and with various
label: paragraph

line: tables’ formats.
label: paragraph

line: WeplantouseTAO’soutputtorecoveratablecells’infor-
label: paragraph

line: mation. To better understand tables (i.e., semantic analysis),
label: paragraph

line: we intend to discover context and semantic relationships for
label: paragraph

line: a table’s information. The relationships exist in the text of a
label: paragraph

line: table’s document, and related datasets. The semantic analy-
label: paragraph

line: sis of tables enables the integration of scientiﬁc knowledge
label: paragraph

line: with the semantic web.
label: paragraph
